standard_metadata.standard_description: Interpret the product (a/b) × q as a parts of a partition of q into b equal parts; equivalently, as the result of a sequence of operations a × q ÷ b.
standard_metadata.standard_title: Multiply fractions and whole numbers visually

question.content: $4$ unit squares each have $\dfrac{4}{5}$ of their area shaded.    **What is $\dfrac{4}{5}$ of $4$?**   square units

images.alt: A row of four identical rectangles. Each rectangle is divided into five equal parts. Each part of each rectangle is labeled one-fifth. The first four parts of each rectangle are shaded. The last part of each rectangle is not shaded.

hints.content: There are $4$ unit squares. $\blueE{\dfrac45}$ of each square is shaded.  [[☃ image 1]]  We can multiply $4 \times \blueE{\dfrac45}$ to find the total shaded area.

images.alt: A row of four identical rectangles. Each rectangle is divided into five equal parts. Each part of each rectangle is labeled one-fifth. The first four parts of each rectangle are shaded. The last part of each rectangle is not shaded.

hints.content: $\begin{align} &\quad~~4 \times \blueE{\dfrac45}\\\\ &=\dfrac{4 \times \blueE4}{\blueE5}\\\\ &=\dfrac{16}{5} \end{align}$
The total shaded area is  $\dfrac{16}{5}$ square units.  This can also be written as $3\dfrac15$ square units.

item.problemType: TYPE 1 - AREA MODEL, REPEATED ADDITION

question.content: $4$ unit squares each have $\dfrac{5}{7}$ of their area shaded.    **What is $\dfrac{5}{7}$ of $4$?**   square units

images.alt: A row of four identical rectangles. Each rectangle is divided into seven equal parts. Each part of each rectangle is labeled one-seventh. The first five parts of each rectangle are shaded. The last two parts of each rectangle are not shaded.

hints.content: There are $4$ unit squares. $\blueE{\dfrac57}$ of each square is shaded.    [[☃ image 1]]  We can multiply $4 \times \blueE{\dfrac57}$ to find the total shaded area.

images.alt: A row of four identical rectangles. Each rectangle is divided into seven equal parts. Each part of each rectangle is labeled one-seventh. The first five parts of each rectangle are shaded. The last two parts of each rectangle are not shaded.

hints.content: $\begin{align} &\quad~~4 \times \blueE{\dfrac57}\\\\ &=\dfrac{4 \times \blueE5}{\blueE7}\\\\ &=\dfrac{20}{7} \end{align}$
The total shaded area is  $\dfrac{20}{7}$ square units.  This can also be written as $2\dfrac67$ square units.

item.problemType: TYPE 1 - AREA MODEL, REPEATED ADDITION

question.content: $5$ unit squares each have $\dfrac{2}{3}$ of their area shaded.    **What is $\dfrac{2}{3}$ of $5$?**   square units

images.alt: A row of five identical rectangles. Each rectangle is divided into three equal parts. Each part of each rectangle is labeled one-third. The first two parts of each rectangle are shaded. The last part of each rectangle is not shaded.

hints.content: There are $5$ unit squares. $\blueE{\dfrac23}$ of each square is shaded.   [[☃ image 1]]  We can multiply $5 \times \blueE{\dfrac23}$ to find the total shaded area.

images.alt: A row of five identical rectangles. Each rectangle is divided into three equal parts. Each part of each rectangle is labeled one-third. The first two parts of each rectangle are shaded. The last part of each rectangle is not shaded.

hints.content: $\begin{align} &\quad~~ 5 \times \blueE{\dfrac23}\\\\ &=\dfrac{5 \times \blueE2}{\blueE3}\\\\ &=\dfrac{10}{3} \end{align}$
The total shaded area is  $\dfrac{10}{3}$ square units.  This can also be written as $3\dfrac13$ square units.

item.problemType: TYPE 1 - AREA MODEL, REPEATED ADDITION

question.content: $6$ unit squares each have $\dfrac{3}{5}$ of their area shaded.    **What is $\dfrac{3}{5}$ of $6$?**   square units

images.alt: Six identical squares. Each square is divided into five equal parts. Each part of each square is labeled one-fifth. The first three parts of each square are shaded. The last two parts of each square are not shaded.

hints.content: There are $6$ unit squares. $\blueE{\dfrac35}$ of each square is shaded.  [[☃ image 1]]  We can multiply $6 \times \blueE{\dfrac35}$ to find the total shaded area.

images.alt: Six identical squares. Each square is divided into five equal parts. Each part of each square is labeled one-fifth. The first three parts of each square are shaded. The last two parts of each square are not shaded.

hints.content: $\begin{align} &\quad~~ 6 \times \blueE{\dfrac35}\\\\ &=\dfrac{6 \times \blueE3}{\blueE5}\\\\ &=\dfrac{18}{5} \end{align}$
The total shaded area is  $\dfrac{18}{5}$ square units.  This can also be written as $3\dfrac35$ square units.

item.problemType: TYPE 1 - AREA MODEL, REPEATED ADDITION

question.content: $6$ unit squares each have $\dfrac{2}{3}$ of their area shaded.     **What is $\dfrac{2}{3}$ of $6$?**   square units

images.alt: Six identical squares. Each square is divided into three equal parts. Each part of each square is labeled one-third. The first two parts of each square are shaded. The last part of each square is not shaded.

hints.content: There are $6$ unit squares. $\blueE{\dfrac23}$ of each square is shaded.  [[☃ image 1]]  We can multiply $6 \times \blueE{\dfrac23}$ to find the total shaded area.

images.alt: Six identical squares. Each square is divided into three equal parts. Each part of each square is labeled one-third. The first two parts of each square are shaded. The last part of each square is not shaded.

hints.content: $\begin{align} &\quad~~ 6 \times \blueE{\dfrac23}\\\\ &=\dfrac{6 \times \blueE2}{\blueE3}\\\\ &=\dfrac{12}{3}\\\\ &=4 \end{align}$
The total shaded area is  $\dfrac{12}{3}$ square units.  This can also be written as $4$ square units.

item.problemType: TYPE 1 - AREA MODEL, REPEATED ADDITION

question.content: Sara wants to multiply $\dfrac14\times8$.  So, she puts $8$ triangles into $4$ equal-sized groups.      **What is $\dfrac14$ of $8$?**

images.alt: A row of eight identical triangles. Lines divide the triangles into 4 groups with 2 triangles each.

hints.content: We see a set of $8$ triangles. The set is split into $4$ equal sections, or *fourths*.
To find $\dfrac14$ of $8$, we can shade $1$ fourth. How many triangles are shaded?    [[☃ image 1]]  $2$ triangles are shaded.

images.alt: A row of eight identical triangles. Lines divide the triangles into 4 groups with 2 triangles each. The first two triangles are shaded.

hints.content: $\dfrac14$ of $8$ equals $2$.

item.problemType: Type 2 - DISCRETE OBJECTS, ANSWER IS WHOLE NUMBER

question.content: Veronica wants to multiply $\dfrac23\times15$.  So, she puts $15$ triangles into $3$ equal-sized groups.     **What is $\dfrac23$ of $15?~~$**

images.alt: Three rows of fifteen identical triangles. Lines divide the triangles into 3 groups with 5 triangles each.

hints.content: We see a set of $15$ triangles. The set is split into $3$ equal sections, or *thirds*.
To find $\dfrac23$ of $15$, we can shade $2$ thirds. How many triangles are shaded?  [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleD{10}$ triangles are shaded.

images.alt: Three rows of fifteen identical triangles. Lines divide the triangles into 3 groups with 5 triangles each. All 5 triangles in the first group and all 5 triangles in the second group are shaded.

hints.content: $\dfrac23$ of $15$ equals $10$.

item.problemType: Type 2 - DISCRETE OBJECTS, ANSWER IS WHOLE NUMBER

question.content: Logan wants to multiply $\dfrac34\times20$.  So, he puts $20$ triangles into $4$ equal-sized groups.     **What is $\dfrac34$ of $20$?**

images.alt: Four rows of twenty identical triangles. Lines divide the triangles into 4 groups with 5 triangles each.

hints.content: We see a set of $20$ triangles. The set is split into $4$ equal sections, or *fourths*.
To find $\dfrac34$ of $20$, we can shade $3$ fourths. How many triangles are shaded?  [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleD{15}$ triangles are shaded.

images.alt: Four rows of twenty identical triangles. Lines divide the triangles into 4 groups with 5 triangles each.  All 5 triangles in the first group, all 5 triangles in the second group, and all 5 triangles in the third group are shaded.

hints.content: $\dfrac34$ of $20$ equals $15$.

item.problemType: Type 2 - DISCRETE OBJECTS, ANSWER IS WHOLE NUMBER

question.content: **Use the following image to find each product.**     $\dfrac13$ of $6=$      $\dfrac23$ of $6=$

images.alt: A row of six identical triangles. Lines divide the triangles into 3 groups of 2 triangles each.

hints.content: We see a set of $6$ triangles. The set is split into $3$ equal sections, or *thirds*.
To find $\dfrac13$ of $6$, we can shade $1$ third. How many triangles are shaded?   [[☃ image 1]]  $2$ triangles are shaded.

images.alt: A row of six identical triangles. Lines divide the triangles into 3 groups of 2 triangles each.  The first two triangles are shaded.

hints.content: To find $\dfrac23$ of $6$, we can shade $2$ thirds. How many triangles are shaded?   [[☃ image 1]]  $4$ triangles are shaded.

images.alt: A row of six identical triangles. Lines divide the triangles into 3 groups of 2 triangles each.  The first four triangles are shaded.

hints.content: $\dfrac13$ of $6$ equals $2$.  $\dfrac23$ of $6$ equals $4$.

item.problemType: Type 2 - DISCRETE OBJECTS, ANSWER IS WHOLE NUMBER

question.content: **Use the following image to find each product.**    $\dfrac{1}{5}\times10=$      $\dfrac{2}{5}\times10=$      $\dfrac{3}{5}\times10=$      $\dfrac{4}{5}\times10=$

images.alt: A row of ten identical triangles. Lines divide the triangles into 5 groups with 2 triangles each.

hints.content: We see a set of $10$ triangles. The set is split into $5$ equal sections, or *fifths*.

$\dfrac{1}{5} \times 10$ is another way of saying $\dfrac{1}{5}$ of $10$.  To find $\dfrac{1}{5}$ of $10$, we can shade $1$ fifth. How many triangles are shaded?  [[☃ image 1]]  We shaded $2$ triangles.

images.alt: A row of ten identical triangles. Lines divide the triangles into 5 groups with 2 triangles each. The first two triangles are shaded.

hints.content: To find $\dfrac{2}{5}$ of $10$, we can shade $2$ fifths.   [[☃ image 1]]  We shaded $4$ triangles.

images.alt: A row of ten identical triangles. Lines divide the triangles into 5 groups with 2 triangles each. The first four triangles are shaded.

hints.content: To find $\dfrac{3}{5}$ of $10$, we can shade $3$ fifths.  [[☃ image 1]]  We shaded $6$ triangles.

images.alt: A row of ten identical triangles. Lines divide the triangles into 5 groups with 2 triangles each. The first six triangles are shaded.

hints.content: To find $\dfrac{4}{5}$ of $10$, we can shade $4$ fifths.  [[☃ image 1]]  We shaded $8$ triangles.

images.alt: A row of ten identical triangles. Lines divide the triangles into 5 groups with 2 triangles each. The first eight triangles are shaded.

hints.content: These are the products.  $\begin{align} \dfrac{1}{5} \times 10 &= 2\\\\ \dfrac{2}{5} \times 10 &= 4\\\\ \dfrac{3}{5} \times 10 &= 6\\\\ \dfrac{4}{5} \times 10 &= 8 \end{align}$

item.problemType: Type 2 - DISCRETE OBJECTS, ANSWER IS WHOLE NUMBER

question.content: **Use the following image to find each product.**    $\dfrac15$ of $15=$      $\dfrac25$ of $15=$      $\dfrac35$ of $15=$      $\dfrac45$ of $15=$

images.alt: A row of fifteen identical squares. Lines divide the squares into 5 groups with 3 squares each.

hints.content: We see a set of $15$ squares. The set is split into $5$ equal sections, or *fifths*.
$\dfrac{1}{5} \times 15$ is another way of saying $\dfrac{1}{5}$ of $15$.  To find $\dfrac{1}{5}$ of $15$, we can shade $1$ fifth. How many squares are shaded?   [[☃ image 1]]  We shaded $3$ squares.

images.alt: A row of fifteen identical squares. Lines divide the squares into 5 groups with 3 squares each.  The first three squares are shaded.

hints.content: To find $\dfrac{2}{5}$ of $15$, we can shade $2$ fifths.   [[☃ image 1]]  We shaded $6$ squares.

images.alt: A row of fifteen identical squares. Lines divide the squares into 5 groups with 3 squares each. The first six squares are shaded.

hints.content: To find $\dfrac{3}{5}$ of $15$, we can shade $3$ fifths.  [[☃ image 1]]  We shaded $9$ squares.

images.alt: A row of fifteen identical squares. Lines divide the squares into 5 groups with 3 squares each. The first nine squares are shaded.

hints.content: To find $\dfrac{4}{5}$ of $15$, we can shade $4$ fifths.  [[☃ image 1]]  We shaded $12$ squares.

images.alt: A row of fifteen identical squares. Lines divide the squares into 5 groups with 3 squares each. The first twelve squares are shaded.

hints.content: $\dfrac15$ of $15$ equals $3$.  $\dfrac25$ of $15$ equals $6$.  $\dfrac35$ of $15$ equals $9$.  $\dfrac45$ of $15$ equals $12$.

item.problemType: Type 2 - DISCRETE OBJECTS, ANSWER IS WHOLE NUMBER

question.content: Use the following image to multiply.    **What is $\dfrac16$ of $2?$**

images.alt: A row of two equal-sized rectangles. Each rectangle is split into 3 equal parts for a total of 6 parts, The first part is shaded and below the shaded part is a curved bracket labeled one-sixth of 2. Above both rectangles is a curved bracket labeled 2.

hints.content: To find $\dfrac{1}{6}$ of $2$, we can split $2$ wholes into $6$ equal pieces.  Each piece represents $\dfrac13$ of one whole:  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A row of two equal-sized rectangles. Each rectangle is split into 3 equal parts for a total of 6 parts, Each  part is labeled one-third. Above each rectangle is a curved bracket labeled 1.

hints.content: Now we can shade $1$ of the $6$ pieces to find $\dfrac16$ of $2$:  [[☃ image 1]]  $\dfrac13$ is shaded.

images.alt: A row of two equal-sized rectangles. Each rectangle is split into 3 equal parts for a total of 6 parts, Each part is labeled one-third. The first part is shaded and below the shaded part is a curved bracket labeled one-sixth of 2.

hints.content: $\dfrac16$ of $2$ equals $\dfrac13$ .

item.problemType: Type 3 - DISCRETE OBJECTS, ANSWER IS FRACTION

question.content: Use the following image to multiply.    **What is $\dfrac58$ of $4?$**

images.alt: A row of four equal-sized rectangles. Each rectangle is split into 2 equal parts for a total of 8 parts, The first 5 parts are shaded and below the shaded parts is a curved bracket labeled five-eighths of 4. Above the row of rectangles is a curved bracket labeled 4.

hints.content: To find $\dfrac{5}{8}$ of $4$, we can split $4$ wholes into $8$ equal pieces.  Each piece represents $\dfrac12$ of one whole:    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A row of four equal-sized rectangles. Each rectangle is split into 2 equal parts for a total of 8 parts. Each  part is labeled one-half. Above each rectangle is a curved bracket labeled 1.

hints.content: Now we can shade $5$ of the $8$ pieces to find $\dfrac{5}{8}$ of $4$:    [[☃ image 1]]  $\dfrac52$ is shaded.

images.alt: A row of four equal-sized rectangles. Each rectangle is split into 2 equal parts for a total of 8 parts. Each part is labeled one-half. The first 5 parts are shaded and below the shaded parts is a curved bracket labeled five-eighths of 4.

hints.content: $\dfrac58$ of $4$ equals $\dfrac52$ .

item.problemType: Type 3 - DISCRETE OBJECTS, ANSWER IS FRACTION

question.content: Use the following image to multiply.    **What is $\dfrac34$ of $2 ? $**

images.alt: A row of two equal-sized rectangles. Each rectangle is split into 2 equal parts for a total of 4 parts, The first three parts are shaded and below the shaded parts is a curved bracket labeled three-fourths of 2. Above both rectangles is a curved bracket labeled 2.

hints.content: To find $\dfrac{3}{4}$ of $2$, we can split $2$ wholes into $4$ equal pieces.  Each piece represents $\dfrac12$ of one whole:   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt:
A row of two equal-sized rectangles. Each rectangle
is split into 2 equal parts for a total of 4 parts, Each
part is labeled one-half. Above each rectangle is a
curved bracket labeled 1.

hints.content: Now we can shade $3$ of the $4$ pieces to find $\dfrac{3}{4}$ of $2$:  [[☃ image 1]]  $\dfrac32$ is shaded.

images.alt:
A row of two equal-sized rectangles. Each rectangle
is split into 2 equal parts for a total of 4 parts, Each
part is labeled one-half. The first 3 parts are shaded
and below the shaded parts is a curved bracket
labeled three-fourths of 2.

hints.content: $\dfrac34$ of $2$ equals $\dfrac32$ .

item.problemType: Type 3 - DISCRETE OBJECTS, ANSWER IS FRACTION

question.content: Use the following image to multiply.    **What is $\dfrac12$ of $5?$**

images.alt: A row of five equal-sized rectangles. Each rectangle is split into 2 equal parts for a total of 10 parts, The first five parts are shaded and below the shaded parts is a curved bracket labeled one-half of 5. Above the row of  rectangles is a curved bracket labeled 5.

hints.content: To find $\dfrac{1}{2}$ of $5$, we can split $5$ wholes into $2$ equal parts.  Each piece represents $\dfrac12$ of one whole:  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt:
A row of five equal-sized rectangles. Each rectangle
is split into 2 equal parts for a total of 10 parts, Each
part is labeled one-half. Above each rectangle is a
curved bracket labeled 1.

hints.content: Now we can shade half of the pieces to find $\dfrac{1}{2}$ of $5$:  [[☃ image 1]]  $\dfrac52$ is shaded.

images.alt:
A row of five equal-sized rectangles. Each rectangle
is split into 2 equal parts for a total of 10 parts, Each
part is labeled one-half. The first 5 parts are shaded
and below the shaded parts is a curved bracket
labeled one half of 5.

hints.content: $\dfrac12$ of $5$ equals $2\dfrac12$ .

item.problemType: Type 3 - DISCRETE OBJECTS, ANSWER IS FRACTION

question.content: Use the following image to multiply.    **What is $\dfrac12$ of $7?$**

images.alt: A row of seven equal-sized rectangles. Each rectangle is split into 2 equal parts for a total of 14 parts, The first seven parts are shaded and below the shaded parts is a curved bracket labeled one-half of 7. Above both rectangles is a curved bracket labeled 7.

hints.content: To find $\dfrac{1}{2}$ of $7$, we can split $7$ wholes into $2$ equal parts.  Each part represents $3\dfrac12$ :  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt:
A row of seven equal-sized rectangles. Each rectangle
is split into 2 equal parts for a total of 14 parts, Each
part is labeled one-half. Above each rectangle is a
curved bracket labeled 1.

hints.content: Now we can shade half of the pieces to find $\dfrac{1}{2}$ of $7$:  [[☃ image 1]]  $\dfrac72$ is shaded.

images.alt:
A row of seven equal-sized rectangles. Each rectangle
is split into 2 equal parts for a total of 14 parts, Each
part is labeled one-half. The first 7 parts are shaded
and below the shaded parts is a curved bracket
labeled one-half of  7.

hints.content: $\dfrac12$ of $7$ equals $3\dfrac12$ .

item.problemType: Type 3 - DISCRETE OBJECTS, ANSWER IS FRACTION

question.content: **Use the following image to multiply.**     $\dfrac45 \times 10=$

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 10 with tick marks every 1 unit. Above the number line is a tape diagram divided into 5 equal parts. 4 parts are shaded. The shaded parts of the tape diagram are between tick mark 0 and tick mark 8 of the number line. The unshaded parts of the tape diagram are between tick mark 8 and tick mark 10.

hints.content: The big rectangle has a length of $10$. It is cut into $5$ equal pieces, or *fifths*.  Each fifth of $10$ has a length of $2$ on the number line:   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 10 with tick marks every 1 unit. Above the number line is a tape diagram divided into 5 equal parts, each labeled one-fifth. A curved bracket across the tape diagram is labeled 10.

hints.content: We can find $\dfrac45$ of $10$ on the number line by counting $4$ lengths of $2$:    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 10 with tick marks every 1 unit. An arrow moves right along the number line from 0 to tick mark 8. Above the number line is a tape diagram divided into 5 equal parts. 4 parts are shaded. The shaded parts of the tape diagram are between tick mark 0 and tick mark 8 of the number line. A curved bracket above the shaded part of the tape diagram is labeled four-fifths times ten.

hints.content: $\dfrac45\times10=8$

item.problemType: TYPE 4 - NUMBER LINES answer is whole number

question.content: **Use the following image to multiply.**    $\dfrac57\times7=$

images.alt: A number line labeled from 0 to 7 with tick marks every 1 unit. Above the number line is a tape diagram divided into 7 equal parts. 5 parts are shaded. The shaded parts of the tape diagram are between tick mark 0 and tick mark 5 of the number line. The unshaded parts of the tape diagram are between tick mark 5 and tick mark 7.

hints.content: The big rectangle has a length of $7$. It is cut into $7$ equal pieces, or *sevenths*.  Each seventh has a length of $1$ on the number line:  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 7 with tick marks every 1 unit. Above the number line is a tape diagram divided into 7 equal parts, each labeled one-seventh. A curved bracket across the tape diagram is labeled 7.

hints.content: We can see where $\dfrac57$ of $7$ is on the number line by counting $5$ lengths of $1$:   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 7 with tick marks every 1 unit. An arrow moves right along the number line from 0 to tick mark 5. Above the number line is a tape diagram divided into 7 equal parts. 5 parts are shaded. The shaded parts of the tape diagram are between tick mark 0 and tick mark 5 of the number line. A curved bracket above the shaded part of the tape diagram is labeled five-sevenths times seven.

hints.content: $\dfrac57\times7=5$

item.problemType: TYPE 4 - NUMBER LINES answer is whole number

question.content: **Use the following image to multiply.**    $\dfrac34\times8 =$

images.alt: A number line labeled from 0 to 8 with tick marks every 1 unit. Above the number line is a tape diagram divided into 4 equal parts. 3 parts are shaded. The shaded parts of the tape diagram are between tick mark 0 and tick mark 6 of the number line. The unshaded parts of the tape diagram are between tick mark 6 and tick mark 8.

hints.content: The big rectangle has a length of $8$. It is cut into $4$ equal pieces, or *fourths*.  Each fourth has a length of $2$ on the number line:  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 8 with tick marks every 1 unit. Above the number line is a tape diagram divided into 4 equal parts, each labeled one-fourth. A curved bracket across the tape diagram is labeled 8.

hints.content: We can see where $\dfrac34$ of $8$ is on the number line by counting $3$ lengths of $2$:  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 8 with tick marks every 1 unit. An arrow moves right along the number line from 0 to tick mark 6. Above the number line is a tape diagram divided into 4 equal parts. 3 parts are shaded. The shaded parts of the tape diagram are between tick mark 0 and tick mark 6 of the number line. A curved bracket above the shaded part of the tape diagram is labeled three-fourths times eight.

hints.content: $\dfrac34\times8=6$

item.problemType: TYPE 4 - NUMBER LINES answer is whole number

question.content: **Use the following image to multiply.**    $\dfrac12\times2=$

images.alt: A number line labeled from 0 to 2 with tick marks every 1 unit. Above the number line is a tape diagram divided into 2 equal parts. 1 part is shaded. The shaded part of the tape diagram is between tick mark 0 and tick mark 1 of the number line. The unshaded part of the tape diagram is between tick mark 1 and tick mark 2.

hints.content: The big rectangle has a length of $2$. It is cut into $2$ equal pieces, or *halves*.  Each half has a length of $1$ on the number line:   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 2 with tick marks every 1 unit. Above the number line is a tape diagram divided into 2 equal parts, each labeled one-half. A curved bracket across the tape diagram is labeled 2.

hints.content: We can see where $\dfrac12$ of $2$ is on the number line by counting $1$ length of $1$:   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 2 with tick marks every 1 unit. An arrow moves right along the number line from 0 to tick mark 1. Above the number line is a tape diagram divided into 2 equal parts. 1 part is shaded. The shaded part of the tape diagram is between tick mark 0 and tick mark 1 of the number line. A curved bracket above the shaded part of the tape diagram is labeled one-half times 2.

hints.content: $\dfrac12\times2=1$

item.problemType: TYPE 4 - NUMBER LINES answer is whole number

question.content: **Use the following image to multiply.**    $\dfrac13\times6=$

images.alt: A number line labeled from 0 to 6 with tick marks every 1 unit. Above the number line is a tape diagram divided into 3 equal parts. 1 part is shaded. The shaded part of the tape diagram is between tick mark 0 and tick mark 2 of the number line. The unshaded parts of the tape diagram are between tick mark 2 and tick mark 6.

hints.content: The big rectangle has a length of $6$. It is cut into $3$ equal pieces, or *thirds*.  Each third has a length of $2$ on the number line:    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 6 with tick marks every 1 unit. Above the number line is a tape diagram divided into 3 equal parts, each labeled one-third. A curved bracket across the tape diagram is labeled 6.

hints.content: We can see where $\dfrac13$ of $6$ is on the number line by counting $1$ lengths of $2$:    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 6 with tick marks every 1 unit. An arrow moves right along the number line from 0 to tick mark 2. Above the number line is a tape diagram divided into 3 equal parts. 1 part is shaded. The shaded part of the tape diagram is between tick mark 0 and tick mark 2 of the number line. A curved bracket above the shaded part of the tape diagram is labeled one-third times six.

hints.content: $\dfrac13$ of $6$ is $2$

item.problemType: TYPE 4 - NUMBER LINES answer is whole number
